abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Power Rehabilitation Project
            inDominica. The main Project objectives were to: (a) provide
            adequate expansion of the generation, transmission, and
            distribution facilities to effect fuel savings and meet the
            growth of electricity consumption between 1989 and 1994; (b)
            strengthen Dominica Electricity ServicesLimited (DOMLEC)
            institutionally by providing outside management services and
            training of technical personnel; and (c) assist DOMLEC in
            planning system expansion to meet its long-term energy
            requirements. While the Borrower feels that Bank performance
            during project preparation was satisfactory, it considers
            that Bank performance during appraisal and supervision was
            not because of the adverse results of the litigation with
            Nord-France. The overall outcome of the Project is deemed to
            be marginally satisfactory because of its likely
            sustainability and because the two main physical and
            institutional objectives were satisfactorily achieved. Key
            lessons learned from the Power Project are: 1) Restrictions
            imposed on the eligibility of bidders and on the size of the
            bidding packages, tend to increase project costs by
            constraining competition and economies of scale in the
            supply of goods, works, and services; 2) projects such as
            this one should reduce the risk of costly litigation by
            providing at the bidding stage a clear definition of
            criteria; 3) To ensure timely, efficient and continuous
            project implementation it is important to guarantee
            continuity of the Project Executing Unit (PEU) principal
            staff; 4) The business of providing electricity services and
            the business of project engineering are very different; and
            5) When formalizing initial positions relating to recently
            awarded large contracts, Borrowers should not hesitate to
            cancel contracts with first winners at the first formal
            indication of intent to renegotiate the value of winning
            bids, and to re-award them to next lowest evaluated bidders.
